nova/scheduler/utils.py.message: Am I missing where the test for this is?
Why are you calling these isolated in one place and forbidden in another?

Thank you for review.
As per [1] comments/discussion changes are done here.
From placement point of view, these are forbidden_aggregates.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671072/6/nova/objects/request_spec.py@1051

Understood 
Will modify Destination.isolated_aggregates to Destination.forbidden_aggregates

Yeah, I realize that. See my comments on the later patch in this series. Here's why I think this is important:

This request spec object will be persisted in the nova database for a potentially long time. What you're doing here, is calculating a list of aggregates which are *currently* (i.e. at the time of the request) configured to be isolated for a given trait. This code will do that calculation and store in the database that "aggregates $foo and $bar are isolated." However, that's true now, but might not be true an hour later when the operator changes the deployment configuration or topology.

While still potentially problematic, storing these aggregates as "forbidden" describes more clearly what will happen if we look at and/or honor this list of aggregate ids.

IMHO, the feature that nova is providing is isolated aggregates, and you've identified that properly. However, aggregates are "isolated" only at some point in time based on a particular config, and thus aren't timeless. The timeless nature of what you're storing here may or may not be good (presumably later there will be a bug where someone complains that a move operation a year later improperly forbids aggregates that were isolated at the time the instance was booted, but no longer are). Regardless, I think properly naming the field we're going to store in the database in perpetuity is important.

Sean's right - we can't just essentially skip this filter for a rebuild. We had a whole CVE saga ([1] [2] and [3]) that resulted in L27 being added, specifically to run rebuild requests through the scheduler to avoid someone rebuilding with a new image on the same compute host to circumvent restrictions on that host/image combo. So we definitely need to run rebuild requests through the NUMATopologyFilter.

Thanks for clarifying on IRC maciej!

I'm still not sure I understand the issue with events/locks. We create a single shared IDL, it grabs the lock, and we watch events for the driver at each start(). Then at shutdown() we stop watching events for that API call's driver.

I'm not that familiar with the actual architecture of the octavia stuff, though. Is the reason we have the lock just because we *used* to do multiple IDLs and wanted to make sure only one handled events? Do we need the lock anymore since we only have one IDL?

Octavia OVN provider driver is responsible for 2 things:
1) Handling the octavia API requests and apply changes on ovn-nb, like: add member to pool
2) Handling incoming OVSDB events related to LRP and LS - for example applying the given LB on LS of network that has been attached to LR, in order to reach LB members from LS network via router.

Unfortunately while setting the lock_name for handling events (responsibility 2), the IDL is configured to need the lock all the time. While using the same IDL for handling Octavia API requests (responsibility 2), the OVSDB transaction fails each time on: "The transaction failed because the IDL has been configured to require a database lock but didn't get it yet or has already lost it" [0]. Thats the ovsdb thing.

So my goal here is to initialize 2 IDLs with 2 active connections to OVN NB DB. One will be configured with lock_name (to prevent two octavia running workers to handle the same events), and the second will be configured without lock_name - to handle API requests. [1]

In next months we'll have possibility to spawn long-running thread in Octavia, just only to handle events (responsibility 2). In this term potentially we could drop this commit from master. Unfortunately we'll still need this in Stein, because the long-running thread will not be cherry-picked to Stein (from Octavia side).

We need to have lock set for events, because other Octavia API instance (yes Octavia could scale) will be handling the same events in the same time.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/master/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/transaction.py#L102
[1] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L445

jenkins/__init__.py.message: So, we're calling get_job_info() with the fullname after using name for the search.  Is this appropriate?  Should we be doing the regex match on the fullname instead of the name?  How should the tests be updated to accommodate this change?  If the tests aren't currently testing this method, they probably should be updated to do so; if they *are* testing this method, then why haven't you needed to update them?

That comes from the patch that added support for the Cloudbees folder plugin: 7267eec4542696b48fea6a07ccdf34c6e887f75f  The bug report on https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-jenkins/+bug/1685575 has an example with the folder/jobs:

 job1
 frontend/front-build
 frontend/front-deploy

The bug hints about:

> Because we're not sending the folder name to _get_job_folder.

So although on line 386 we match both 'front-build' and 'front-deploy' jobs, we attempt to get their job information using solely the base name.  _get_job_folder thus yields nothing since no jobs exist by that name.


So indeed we need to pass the fullname, so get_job_info() can use the folder to look it up. The match will still be done solely on the job base name though which match the method description.


There are some tests in tests/jobs/test_info.py test_regex().  I gave it a try this evening, but eventually gave up trying to mock the jenkins_open return based on the Request given.

I believe my summary above is sufficient to justify merging this without tests.

nova/conf/libvirt.py.message: somewhere in here it should say that this setting is ignored if we detect that your host doesn't support memory encrypted guests
I think the default should be 0? this doesn't sounds like a feature we enabled by default

Yeah, given that the auto-detection isn't possible and we have nothing wired up to do this, I don't think we should be handling this. We can always change the behavior of the option in a future release, but for now I'd make 0 and None equivalent and drop references to this imaginary (for now) auto-detection feature.

This design was already carefully considered, e.g. in discussions in April while drafting the spec:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/641994/6/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.rst@192

and also later in May:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-05-28.log.html#t2019-05-28T18:44:14

It was Eric's idea to default to None (meaning "auto-detect if possible, otherwise leave unlimited"), and I see no serious problem with having this default, because:

- It won't affect compute nodes which can't do SEV.
- By default it won't affect *any* compute nodes or VMs: VMs won't randomly boot with SEV, because you still need to specifically request SEV via a flavor or image property.

Additionally it avoids requiring operators to manually tweak nova.conf on every SEV machine they deploy before they can use SEV.  That might not be too convincing an argument in the short-term, but in the long-term it means that some nova-compute upgrade would make compute nodes automagically detect the correct limit.  If the limit is set manually in the short term, operators would then have to manually remove that limit as soon as auto-detection arrives.  IOW that's two sets of manual configuration, probably for little to no gain (see below).

We definitely don't want 0 and None to be equivalent, because for sure we need operators to be able to:

- manually disable SEV on a machine which is SEV-capable, by setting to 0
- set to "auto-detect if you can"

and it's probably still useful for some operators to be able to set it to unlimited.

If you're really worried about the unlimited case, I could maybe be persuaded to change the default from None to 0.  Maybe we could even use -1 to indicate unlimited and None to indicate "auto-detect if you can, otherwise 0".  But that's getting complicated to understand.  Also please bear in mind that on the latest Rome generation of EPYC hardware, the number of hardware slots is something like 500, which on many machines (and depending on the size of the smallest flavors available) could easily be more than the available RAM permits anyway, meaning that it would be impossible to exceed the number of SEV slots available.  So I'd prefer to give the operator the option of "unlimited", even if it's not the default.

In summary I'm not yet convinced this should be changed.  However if you can persuade Eric otherwise then you can probably persuade me too :-)

nova/compute/api.py.message: nit: technically you don't need this since you could do 'f.__name__' (or some variation of that), right?
Yeah, that's a good point. Explicit is better than implicit

Yeah I did think about that, but am wary of trying to be too clever with meta-programming as it can obfuscate things.  Perhaps more importantly the call stack could change in the future or the function get renamed so it felt a bit brittle to do that.
Might be better to use instance_actions.SUSPEND here.

Reason being the instance actions are the thing the end users sees "on the outside". The compute API function name doesn't mean much to them, so using the instance action correlates to the actual server action they are performing in the API.
This call could raise FlavorImageConflict in theory but it won't in practice. If there is conflict then the instance was failed to boot so neither suspend nor live_migrate can be called on it.

Quick question: Should we add a match condition here to make sure that the port "up" attribute didn't change from True ?

For example: __init__(events, table,(('up', '=', True),), old_conditions=(('up', '=', True),))
If we override match_fn, it replaces the checking for conditions.
Oh right, I thought it was complementary
Should we make the old parameter mandatory since we are using it without actually checking it's type value ? The default type (None) will result in a exception here (AttributeError)

That's just what match_fn() looks like at the abstract level. We don't have to check on this though because we are only ROW_UPDATE type, which always sends an 'old'. I'm not sure what the rule would be for changing a method signature that is called internally by a library that we don't control (normally ovsdbapp, but we define it above because we didn't want to depend on the latest ovsdbapp). I'm happy to change it, just wasn't sure about what the style rules were.
Gotcha! Yeah it just looks like it could crash. Maybe a small comment so other people looking at this code do not see this as a potential problem ?

We have seeing cases which events may take a while to be processed when the driver is under heavy load and if the port is deleted before this event kicks in it will raise a RowNotFound exception. I think we should handle it here to be on the safe side.

I was thinking that exceptions were caught by ovsdbapp code, but that is for run() in notify_loop(), but not for notify() which is where match_fn() ultimately would stem from. That's in python-ovs code. It too wraps it in a try/except: log() already as well though https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L605

Is there something custom we should do on a RowNotFound, or should we let python-ovs handle it?

Thanks for the links. I think the benefit of handling it here is that we can LOG a proper message (with the right log level) for this specific problem (e.g a warning for it). Or, if we do not want to log anything we can just ignore the RowNotFound since it's not a problem and move on.

The problem with python-ovs handling it IMHO is because it will end up logging it as an actual error [0] (the level) which (almost) always confuses operators looking at those logs.

[0] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/15b527e2dc03e2caad4c0fa3a00afd63131707e1/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L611-L612

Yeah, paranoid me wanted to suggest bool(lsp.up) :) I don't think it will hurt us.

Eagle eyes.

The best I can find in the rfc is:

 The operation inserts "row" into "table".  If "row" does not specify
   values for all the columns in "table", those columns receive default
   values.  The default value for a column depends on its type.  The
   default for a column whose <type> specifies a "min" of 0 is an empty
   set or empty map.  Otherwise, the default is a single value or a
   single key-value pair, whose value(s) depend on its <atomic-type>:

   o  "integer" or "real": 0

   o  "boolean": false

   o  "string": "" (the empty string)

   o  "uuid": 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000

so it looks like the default for boolean is false, but min 0 means []. Doing:

    ovn-nbctl lsp-add test_sw test_port -- list Logical_Switch_Port test_port

confirms it is briefly [], but I assume that by the time we are getting a Port_Binding event referencing the LSP that it will be set to true/false? I can add return bool(lsp.up) just to be sure I suppose.

I would suggest not mix `.Values.network.interface.tunnel` with dpdk. `.Values.network.interface.tunnel` can be any device which has an ip address. For no dpdk driven device, this should be NIC name. For dpdk driven device, this should be the bridge name. The bridge ip is migrated from the dpdk NIC.
This should make things easier.

we define dpdk section as:
```
  ovs_dpdk:
    enabled: false
    driver: uio_pci_generic
    nics:
      - name: dpdk0
        pci_id: '0000:05:00.0'
        bridge: br-phy
        migrate_ip: true
    bridges:
      - name: br-phy
```
1. We create bridge for each item in 'ovs_dpdk.bridges'
2. For each item in 'ovs_dpdk.nics', we bind it to the driver and add it to bridge. If migrate_ip is defined as true and the nic indeed has an ip address, we migrate the ip to the bridge.
This is almost the same as your last version patch, we just add IP migration.

based on Cheng's comment, I changed the logic here in comparison to a previous patch: "tunnel_interface" is not the NIC anymore which gets bound to DPDK, but the bridge to which the NIC is assigned. From a users perspective this is more intuitive because you also specify the device (bridge or NIC) which should eventually be used as tunnel interface. This means that in case of DPDK, tunnel_interface is "br-phy".

Further up in the code, based on the "nics" config section, all NICs get bound to DPDK and their IP migrated to the specified bridge. In the default config, this is br-phy which will eventually act as tunnel interface.

The main challenge I see is that auto_bridge_add uses interfaces names instead of PCI ids. Once bound to DPDK, NICs cannot be referred to with their kernel provided names. Moreover, auto_bridge_add uses colons as separators, which unfortunately are part of PCI IDs...
```
auto_bridge_add:

    datapath_type: netdev
    nic:
      name: interface_name
      type: dpdk
      pci_id: 0000:05:00.0
```

dcmanagerclient/openstack/common/gettext.message:
I believe there is a problem here.
gettext.install has a different signature in python2 and python3.

In python2 there is a unicode argument.
In python3 there is not (and not a str arg either)

Ex:
python2.7
import inspect
import gettext
print(inspect.getargspec(gettext.install))

ArgSpec(args=['domain', 'localedir', 'unicode', 'codeset', 'names'], varargs=None, keywords=None, defaults=(None, False, None, None))


python3
import inspect
import gettext
print(inspect.getargspec(gettext.install))

ArgSpec(args=['domain', 'localedir', 'codeset', 'names'], varargs=None, keywords=None, defaults=(None, None, None))

You are right, actually, I was so blind that I didn't notice the if six.PY3: 
A boolean indicating if the code is running on Python 3. Thanks a lot for the time taken to review

There are 2 possible use cases here:
* When a VM is terminated or fails to spawn, Nova needs to call Cyborg to delete the ARQs. But Nova does not store the ARQ UUIDs. SO, it calls with "instance=..." form.

* An operator or script may want to delete a specific ARQ, may be from cyborg client, if something goes wrong. Also, in the future, if we support hot add/delete of accelerators, we may want to delete specific ARQs for hot-delete. The 'uuids='..." form helps with that.

The Nova code maps each request group to a resource provider. The Cyborg code should map each ARQ to a request group, so that Nova can locate the RP for each ARQ, as in [2].

The Cyborg REST API have been designed for collections, i.e., they can manipulate more than one object at a time for efficiency. That is because it is easier to use a N-object API for N=1 than to use a 1-object API for multiple objects. However, based on feedback from Cyborg folks and others, I also added uuid as a primary key, so that we can get/delete a single device profile by uuid. This can be useful if we want to allow renaming of device profiles in the future.

The convention is to address single objects by uuid. Multiple objects are addressed by name because that is most user-friendly, but we are not precluding having value=uuid1,uuid2,... in the future.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I am just curious how _create_backup will solve the permission issue?

So the difference is the way the cleanup is being done. At the instance-level the cleanup is done as such:

        self.addCleanup(backup_client.delete_backup, backup['id'])

And in the rbac_base.py, the cleanup for _create_backup is done as such:

        self.addClassResourceCleanup(
            test_utils.call_and_ignore_notfound_exc,
            backup_client.delete_backup, backup['id'])

When using the 'addClassResourceCleanup' the volume backup is deleted with no leak. When using 'addCleanup' the volume backup does not delete and the following error message is seen when executing 'openstack volume backup show <volume_backup>':

fail_reason:
Object DELETE failed: http://ceph-rgw.xxxxx.xxxxx.xxxxxxx.local:xxxx/swift/v1/KEY_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx/volumebackups/volume_ad1efb0c-56ad-4401-bd13-6492c0b218b9/20190816193031/az_nova_backup_c89a5dc3-6a6e-47f5-8c86-5771cc1cc56f-00010 401 Una

I do not know enough about 'addClassResourceCleanup' to explain why/how it is able to delete the volume backup, but just know that when using that there is no volume backup leak.
